table_items.text: ROUTINE POSTNATAL CARE OF WOMEN AND THEIR BABIES

clarification to point 4.7 – approved by James Day

data.text: INDEX
Purpose
To identify the essential, and best practical advice, on core (routine) care that every patient and her baby should receive in the first 28 days after birth, based on the best evidence available.
To ensure there is good communication between healthcare professionals and the
patient and her family. Communication should be supported by the provision of evidence based information.
To ensure information is offered in a form that is tailored to the needs of the individual patient.
Equality Impact Assessment
Mid Essex Hospitals Services NHS Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
(Refer to Appendix E)
Background
Although for most patients and babies the postnatal period is uncomplicated, care during this period needs to address any deviation from expected recovery after birth.

Patients and their families should always be treated with kindness, respect and dignity. The views, beliefs, values and cultural preferences of the patient, her partner and her family in relation to her care and that of her baby should be sought and respected at all times. Birth Partners will not routinely be offered the option of staying overnight on the Postnatal Ward; however if there are exceptional circumstances these can be discussed on a case by case basis, based on clinical need e.g. severe mental health problems.

Patients should have the opportunity to make informed decisions about their care and any treatment needed. Where a patient does not have the capacity to make decisions, healthcare professionals should follow the guidance in the Trust's ‘Consent to treatment policy.
All information should be provided in a form that is accessible to patients, their partners and families, taking into account any additional needs, such as physical, cognitive or
sensory disabilities and people who do not speak or read English.
Care Planning in the Postnatal Period

A coordinating healthcare professional should be identified for each patient. Whilst in a Hospital setting the healthcare professional will be identified on a shift basis. In the home setting the health care professional will be the visiting midwife. The needs of the patient and baby may change and therefore the professional may change over time.

An individualised postnatal care plan should be developed with the patient ideally in the antenatal period or as soon as possible after birth, and documented in the patient's postnatal maternity health care records.
The postnatal care plan should include the following information and be reviewed at each postnatal contact:
Relevant factors from the antenatal, intrapartum and immediate postnatal period
Details of the healthcare professionals involved in her care and that of her baby, including roles and contact details
Plans for the postnatal period

A full physical and psychological assessment should be undertaken at each postnatal contact and discussions should be documented in the postnatal maternity healthcare records, identifying any specific problems and follow-up. (Refer to section 5)
The health care professional should discuss the length of stay in the maternity unit with the patient. The length of stay should take into account the health and well-being of the patient.
Mothers should be encouraged to mobilise as soon as it is appropriate to prevent the development of a thromboembolism.
If a woman has been an inpatient for at least 48 hours and is unlikely to be discharged before  hours, a full MRSA screen should be undertaken.
Maternal Physical Examination
The examination should be completed at each postnatal contact on an individual basis and findings recorded in the postnatal records.
The physical examination should include the following assessments:
Routine observation of involution of the uterus by abdominal palpation/measurement in the absence of abnormal vaginal loss is unnecessary.
If the vaginal loss is assessed as abnormal i.e. excessive or offensive, assessment of uterine involution and position should be undertaken by abdominal palpation
A minimum of one blood pressure should be taken and documented in the patient's healthcare records within 6 hours of birth.
Patients should have their observations as a minimum recorded twice a day on the Modified Early Obstetric Warning System (MEOWS) chart to include:
(Refer to the guideline entitled ‘Management of the severely ill pregnant patient; register number 09095)
Temperature
Pulse
Respiratory rate
Blood pressure (BP) systolic and diastolic with mean arterial pressure (MAP) recordings
For inpatients who have undergone a surgical procedure who are asymptomatic, the temperature should be recorded as indicated by the patients clinical condition.
Routine assessment of proteinuria is not recommended.
For patients with a history of pregnancy induced hypertension/pre-eclampsia/
eclampsia, the monitoring of the blood pressure will be determined on an individual
basis.

Patients whom have had a regional anaesthesia or general anaesthetic should be advised to inform the health care professional if they experience a severe headache, particularly if it occurs whilst sitting/standing
To enable assessment of the perineum, patients should be asked if they are experiencing any of the following:
pain
discomfort
stinging
offensive odour
If a patient reports any of the above, the midwife should offer to assess the perineum.

Following inspection of the perineum, if there are any signs and symptoms of infection, wound breakdown, non-healing or inadequate repair, a swab should be taken prior to any treatment. This assessment and action should be documented in the patient's health care records and medical opinion sought.
Where perineal trauma has occurred the midwife should assess the perineum on day  prior to discharge from midwifery care.
Patients should be advised on pain relieving therapies and general perineal hygiene.

Patients should be asked if they have opened their bowels within 3 days of birth. A Patient's usual bowel habit should be taken into consideration and appropriate advice given regarding diet and fluid intake and avoidance of constipation.
If a patient has faecal incontinence, she should be referred to her named consultant
obstetrician who will assess the degree of incontinence and make a referral to the
appropriate professional. In addition, the patient should be referred to the physiotherapist as for point 5.19.
Patients should be encouraged to pass urine within 6 hours of birth – the volume, if in a
hospital setting, should be documented in the health care records. If the patient is unable to pass urine
(Refer to the ‘Guideline for the management of bladder care in pregnancy';
register number 09007)
All patients should be educated and encouraged to undertake pelvic floor exercises as soon as possible following birth to assist with tone, control and perineal healing.

If a patient has involuntarily leakage of urine which is either unresolved by pelvic floor exercises, or becoming worse, the patient should be referred to the continence nurse advisor/ urology nurse/ dedicated catheter nurse experienced in bladder retraining (contact number 01245-318518) or continence physiotherapist (contact number 01245 514198). (Refer to the ‘Guideline for the management of bladder care in pregnancy'; register number 09007)
Assessment of the patient's breasts and nipples should be undertaken and advice given on lactation and correct positioning of the baby if breast feeding.
(Refer to the ‘Guideline for the management of breast feeding in the postnatal period'.
Register number 09111)
Patients should be advised to report any signs and symptoms of mastitis and appropriate advice given.

Patients who choose to artificially feed their baby should be advised on suppression of lactation. (Refer to the ‘Guideline for the management of artificial feeding in the postnatal period'. Register number 09110)
Patients calves should be assessed for any unilateral calf pain, redness or swelling and medical advice sought if findings abnormal.
The midwife should discuss contraception with the patient at the discharge postnatal contact.
A haemoglobin level should be performed on patients who have had a postpartum haemorrhage or have persistent fatigue and appropriate treatment undertaken.
If a patient requires Anti-D, this should be offered and administered within 72 hours of birth.

Prior to discharge home; or in the case of a Homebirth, prior to the midwife leaving, women should be given written information about the signs and symptoms of infection within 24 hours of birth. If however the woman is too unwell to receive this information or the woman is well but has a very poorly baby (e.g. transferred to a Tertiary Unit for treatment), the midwife should assess the woman on an individual basis and provide a discussion and give written information about the signs and symptoms of infection as appropriate.
Postnatal Contacts

Patients should be offered an opportunity to talk about their birth experiences and to ask questions about the care that they received during labour. This should be documented in the patient's healthcare records.
Patients should be advised of the signs and symptoms of postpartum haemorrhage,
infection, pre-eclampsia/eclampsia and thrombo-embolism. If patients experience any signs and symptoms, they should be advised to contact their health care professional immediately, or call 999.
As postnatal depression can affect 10% of women, patients should be asked about their emotional wellbeing, support and coping strategies to establish if additional support is
required.
(Refer to the ‘Guideline for the identification and management of patients with mental ill
health during the perinatal period', Register number 09090)
Patients and their families should be encouraged to inform the midwife or health care professional if the mother experiences any changes in their mood, behaviour and
emotional condition which is outside of their normal pattern.
At the discharge postnatal visit (normally  days following birth), the patient should be asked if any symptoms of baby blues have resolved. If symptoms remain, the patient
should be assessed for postnatal depression. Where the Midwife suspects postnatal
depression, she should specifically ask the questions below that we should document in the postnatal records:
“In the last month, have you been bothered by:
“Severe depression, such as feeling extreme unnecessary worry, being unable to concentrate due to distraction from depressive feelings.”
“Severe anxiety, such as uncontrollable feeling of panic, being unable to cope or becoming obsessive.”
“The desire to hurt others or yourself, including thoughts about taking your own life.”
“Confused and disturbed thoughts, which could include other people telling you that you are imagining things.”
Parents should be offered advice and information to enable them to assess their baby's general health, identify signs and symptoms of common health problems, and how to
contact the appropriate health professionals for further advice.
All visits at home should be used as an opportunity to assess relevant safety issues for the family and the environment. Additionally, it should be used to promote health and
safety education.

All visits at home should be used as an opportunity to assess parent-baby attachment. If the midwife suspects that natural bonding is not happening, where possible, she should ask the partner if he/she has any concerns. (This can be recorded under ‘comments: any issues raised by partner'). If the midwife has concerns in this area, she should communicate her concerns to the Health Visitor or to the woman's GP.
Infant Feeding
(Refer to the ‘Guideline for the management of breast feeding in the postnatal period'.
Register number 09111; and the ‘Guideline for the management of artificial feeding in the postnatal period'. Register number 09110)
Infants will be managed for the duration of their hospital stay using the flowchart ‘Infant feeding care Pathway' (Appendix B)

All infants will be weighed on day 5 and if breastfeeding a breastfeeding assessment (appendix C) should be completed to support successful breastfeeding. Women should be provided with information on local support including the infant feeding specialist midwife's contact details.

Babies with weight loss of greater than 10% but less than 15% should be managed using the 12% weight loss pathway (appendix D) and wherever possible should remain in the community. However, any baby where underlying illness is suspected should be referred for paediatric review.
Infant Examination

At each postnatal contact, a baby examination should be performed with parental consent and documented in the patient's health care records (Refer to Guideline for the examination of the newborn infant'. Register number 04225; to include points 8.1 to 8.3)
This examination should include assessment of:
Feeding
Colour
Activity
Elimination of urine
Elimination of meconium/stool
For a full list of the examination requirements, refer to Guideline for examination of the Newborn register Number 04225
A full formal examination should be performed within 72 hours of birth.
The neonatal blood spot screening (NBSS) should be offered to parents when the baby is 5 -8 days of age.
Ideally, newborn hearing screening should be offered prior to discharge from a hospital setting.

For those babies discharge prior to a hearing screening or born at home, the screening should be followed up by MEHT Newborn hearing screening team; telephone number 01245513291. An appointment should be offered at a clinic within the mother's home area or of her choice.
Parents should be advised on care of their baby's skin and if needed, only a mild non perfumed soap should be used.
Parents should be advised to keep the umbilicus clean and dry. Antiseptics should not be  used routinely.
Parent should be advised to contact a health care professional if their baby is jaundiced or jaundice is worsening.

Babies who develop jaundice within 24 hours of birth should be referred to the paediatrician. Jaundice which develops after 24 hours of birth should be monitored in conjunction with the baby's general health (Refer to the ‘Guideline for the management of breast feeding in the postnatal period'. Register number 09111; the ‘Guideline for the management of artificial feeding in the postnatal period'. Register number 09110; and the ‘Guideline for the management of neonatal hyperbilirubinemia'. Register number 09094)
Unless there are specific risk factors, for example, maternal pyrexia during labour, prolonged rupture of membranes, the baby's temperature does not need to be taken routinely.

If a baby is suspected of being unwell and a temperature is required, this should be taken using the digital thermometer. A temperature of 38C or above is considered abnormal, and should be discussed with the paediatrician.
(Refer to Guideline for the examination of the newborn infant'. Register number 04225)
Vitamin K

All parents should be offered vitamin K prophylaxis for their babies to prevent the rare but serious (sometimes fatal) vitamin K deficiency bleeding disorder (Refer to the guideline for the ‘Administration of vitamin K'. Register number 08095; to include points 9.1 to 9.3)
Ideally, vitamin K should be administered as a single 1mg dose intramuscular injection.
If parents declined intramuscular vitamin K, they should be offered oral vitamin K and advised this will require 3 doses as per manufacturer's instructions.
Information for Parents

Patients should be given the New Baby Guide ideally at 36 weeks gestation; however if this should not occur i.e. late booker or out of area woman; the information should be discussed and given on an individual basis up until term or prior to discharge from the maternity unit / following a home birth and recorded in the health care records.
The booklet offers information on the physiological and emotional changes following birth, and common health concerns, and should be discussed with the patient.
The booklet will provide information on the health of both the patient and baby. It will provide parents with information to assess their baby's health, identify any signs or
symptoms of common problems and if action needs to be taken.

In addition, information leaflets should be given and discussed as indicated on the Postnatal Care Record – Baby; this includes signs that your baby is unwell, sudden infant death syndrome and co-sleeping.

The Midwife responsible for the birth should give the personal child health record to patients. The Health Professional who completes the Newborn Initial Physical Examination (NIPE) check should document the findings on page 3 of this book. The hearing screener should document the results of the initial hearing test on page  The health visitor is responsible for explaining the child health record to the parents.
The information provided and discussed should be completed in the Postnatal Care  Record
Transfer between Care Settings and Health Care Professional
(Refer to ‘Guideline for the transfer of mothers and their babies to different care settings'.  Register number 06029)

A midwife transfer and personal face to face handover from labour ward to the postnatal ward should be carried out and documented in the patient's maternity health care records, unless conditions prevent this i.e. busy periods. If a personal face to face handover is not possible at time of transfer, there should be a midwife to midwife verbal handover via the telephone, followed by a face to face handover as soon as it is possible. (Refer to guideline for ‘Handover of care in maternity'. Register number 10001)

The postnatal handover page in the Postnatal Care Record should be completed by the midwife receiving the patient from the labour ward. This tool provides information on the wellbeing of both the patient and the baby, and provides the opportunity to identify an individual plan of care.
(Refer to guideline for ‘Handover of care in maternity'. Register number 10001)
When a patient is transferred from the Postnatal Ward to a midwife led birthing unit for ongoing post natal care, this handover page should be reviewed by the midwife who is taking over the care.
For those patients and babies being transferred form the consultant unit to the midwife- led unit, there should be a verbal handover.
(Refer to guideline for ‘Handover of care in maternity'. Register number 10001)

When patients are discharged home from the consultant unit to community care, the discharge book on the postnatal ward or in the Co-Located Birthing Unit should be completed. For those patients outside of Chelmsford community, the relevant hospital should be informed of the discharge, providing the relevant information as documented in the discharge book.
In the event a patient and /or baby is transferred from the community or midwife led unit to the consultant unit, there should be a verbal handover between the referring
professional and the receiving professional and the completion of the transfer proforma
(Refer to ‘Guideline for the transfer of mothers and their babies to different care settings'. Register number 06029)

Mothers and babies that are either transferred or readmitted to the unit should have an assessment undertaken within 30 minutes; once the woman and/or her baby have been shown to her bed or assessment area.
Postpartum Haemorrhage
In the event of a sudden or profuse blood loss, or blood loss with signs and symptoms of shock, further assessment of the patient should be made and midwifery and medical assistance sought
(Refer to the 'Guideline for the management of postpartum haemorrhage'. Register number 04234)
Genital Tract Sepsis
If infection is suspected, the patient's temperature should be taken and documented in the patient's the health care records.

If the temperature is above 38 degrees centigrade, the temperature should be repeated in one hour and paracetamol 1g should be offered orally/ intravenously as prescribed; if there are no related allergies.

If the temperature remains above  degrees centigrade on the second reading (2 hours later), or there are observable signs and symptoms, further assessment of the patient's condition should be made and midwifery and medical assistance sought. Blood cultures should be obtained with prior consent by the obstetric senior house officer for analysis.
Pre-eclampsia/Eclampsia

Patients with severe or persistent headaches should be assessed and pre-eclampsia considered. (Refer to the ‘Guideline for the management of eclampsia and pre-eclampsia'. Register Number 05110; to include points 14.1 to11.4)
If the diastolic measurement is greater than 90 mm Hg but there are no signs or symptoms of pre-eclampsia, the blood pressure should be repeated in 4 hours.
If the second diastolic measurement remains greater than 90 mm Hg, and there is an additional signs/symptom of pre-eclampsia, medical assistance should be sought.
If the diastolic blood pressure remains above  mm Hg and does not fall to below  mm Hg within 4 hours, medical assistance should be sought.
Thromboembolism
If a patient experiences shortness of breath or chest pain, the potential for a pulmonary thrombosis should be considered and medical assistance sought.
The blood pressure, pulse, respirations and oxygen saturation measurements should be performed to assess patient wellbeing.
Patients with a raised body mass index (BMI) greater than 35 have an increased risk of a Thromboembolism
(Refer to the ‘Guideline for the management of antenatal thromboprophylaxis'; register number 08014)
Postnatal Visiting following Discharge from a Consultant or Midwife- led Unit
(Refer to Appendix A)

All patients should have the contact details for the relevant unit, or local hospital if out of area for Mid Essex Hospital Services NHS Trust. These details will be available on the discharge information envelope and confirmation these have been given documented in the Postnatal Care Record – Maternal.
The midwife undertaking the discharge should discuss the arrangements for community midwifery care with the patient and document when and how the first contact will take place.

For patients discharged from the consultant-led unit; the community midwifery team should be advised of all discharges from the Postnatal Ward by the ward clerk, or in her absence, the shift coordinator of the Postnatal Ward.
Patients should be visited the following day at home by their named midwife or a member of the community midwifery team.
If the first postnatal visit is at the weekend, mothers should be offered a home visit or an appointment at the postnatal clinic held at the Consultant-led Unit, Broomfield Hospital.

All healthcare professionals who care for pregnant and recently delivered women should adhere to local infection control protocols and be aware of the signs and symptoms of sepsis in the women they care for and the need for urgent assessment; to include undertaking maternal observations (temperature, respirations, pulse and blood pressure) and treatment. This is particularly the case for community midwives, who may be the first to pick up any potentially abnormal signs during their routine postnatal observations for all women, not just those who have had a caesarean section. If puerperal infection is suspected, the woman must be referred back to the obstetric services as soon as possible.

Follow up visits are determined by clinical need but as a minimum first time mothers should be seen on three occasions(transfer, day 5 and discharge) and second time mothers and thereafter should be seen twice (transfer, day 5 and discharge). Additional support visits are offered by community maternity care assistants or community midwife on an individual basis.
For patients discharged from the consultant unit who have a Braintree, Maldon or Witham Midwife; the ward clerk should ring the birthing units to advise them of all discharges for
their area. At the weekend this is done by the shift coordinator on the postnatal ward.
Patients should be seen at home the following day.
At weekends patients may be offered the choice of an appointment at the birthing units or a home visit. Visiting schedules are the same.
Patients discharged from the midwife-led unit are handed directly over to their named
midwife. If she is not on duty, the visit should be recorded in the community diary for the area in which the mother lives.
Staffing and Training
All midwifery and obstetric staff must attend yearly mandatory training which includes skills and drills training.
All midwifery and obstetric staff are to ensure that their knowledge and skills are up-to-date in order to complete their portfolio for appraisal.
Professional Midwifery Advocates

Professional Midwifery Advocates provide a mechanism of support and guidance to women and midwives. Professional Midwifery Advocates are experienced practising midwives who have undertaken further education in order to supervise midwifery services and to advise and support midwives and women in their care choices.
Infection Prevention
All staff should follow Trust guidelines on infection prevention by ensuring that they effectively ‘decontaminate their hands' before and after each procedure.

All staff should ensure that they follow Trust guidelines on infection prevention. All invasive devices must be inserted and cared for using High Impact Intervention guidelines to reduce the risk of infection and deliver safe care. This care should be recorded in the Saving Lives High Impact Intervention Monitoring Tool Paperwork (Medical Devices).
Audit and Monitoring

Audit of compliance with this guideline will be considered on an annual audit basis in accordance with the Clinical Audit Strategy and Policy (register number 08076), the Corporate Clinical Audit and Quality Improvement Project Plan and the Maternity annual audit work plan; to encompass national and local audit and clinical governance identifying key harm themes. The Women's and Children's Clinical Audit Group will identify a lead for the audit.
As a minimum the following specific requirements will be monitored:

Documentation of information given to enable parent(s) to assess their newborn's general condition and identify any signs and symptoms of common health problems to enable parent(s) to respond to problems
Documentation that parent(s) have been given contact details for the relevant healthcare professionals regardless of the place of birth
Documentation of the coordinating healthcare professional for women with multiagency or multidisciplinary needs
Process for developing an individualised postnatal care plan
System for postnatal visiting once the woman has been discharged from the hospital/midwifery led unit
Documentation in the health records of all of the above
Process for audit, multidisciplinary

A review of a suitable sample of health records of patients to include the minimum requirements as highlighted in point  will be audited. A minimum compliance 75% is required for each requirement. Where concerns are identified more frequent audit will be undertaken.

The findings of the audit will be reported to and approved by the Multi-disciplinary Risk Management Group (MRMG) and an action plan with named leads and timescales will be developed to address any identified deficiencies. Performance against the action plan will be monitored by this group at subsequent meetings.
The audit report will be reported to the monthly Directorate Governance Meeting (DGM) and significant concerns relating to compliance will be entered on the local Risk Assurance Framework.
Key findings and learning points from the audit will be submitted to the Patient Safety Group within the integrated learning report.
Key findings and learning points will be disseminated to relevant staff.
Guideline Management

As an integral part of the knowledge, skills framework, staff are appraised annually to ensure competency in computer skills and the ability to access the current approved guidelines via the Trust's intranet site.

Quarterly memos are sent to line managers to disseminate to their staff the most currently approved guidelines available via the intranet and clinical guideline folders, located in each designated clinical area.

Guideline monitors have been nominated to each clinical area to ensure a system whereby obsolete guidelines are archived and newly approved guidelines are now downloaded from the intranet and filed appropriately in the guideline folders. ‘Spot checks' are performed on all clinical guidelines quarterly.
Quarterly Clinical Practices group meetings are held to discuss ‘guidelines'. During this meeting the practice development midwife can highlight any areas for future training
needs will be met using methods such as ‘workshops' or to be included in future ‘skills and drills' mandatory training sessions.
Communication

A quarterly ‘maternity newsletter' is issued to all staff to highlight key changes in clinical practice to include a list of newly approved guidelines for staff to acknowledge and familiarise themselves with and practice accordingly. Midwives that are on maternity leave or ‘bank' staff have letters sent to their home address to update them on current clinical changes.
Approved guidelines are published monthly in the Trust's Staff Focus that is sent via email to all staff.
Approved guidelines will be disseminated to appropriate staff quarterly via email.
Regular memos are posted on the guideline and audit notice boards in each clinical area to notify staff of the latest revised guidelines and how to access guidelines via the
intranet or clinical guideline folders.
References
Centre for Maternal and Child Enquiries (2011) Executive Summary (CMACE), BJOG 118 (Suppl. 1), e12–e21
Department of Health (2007) Maternity Matters: Choice, access and continuity of care in a safe service. London: COI
National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence (2006) Routine postnatal care of women and their babies. CG37; London: NICE

Appendix B
Infant Feeding Care Pathway
Appendix C
Name…………………………………. Hospital number……………………………….
Breastfeeding Assessment Tool
To be completed for all breastfeeding mothers prior to discharge from hospital (ideally within first 24 hours), day 5 and day 10 or if any concerns are identified.

table_items.text: How you and your midwife can recognise that your baby is feeding well
Your baby: has at least 8 -12 feeds in 24 hours*
is generally calm and relaxed when feeding and content after most feeds
will take deep rhythmic sucks and you will hear swallowing*
will generally feed for between 5 and 40 minutes and will come off the breast spontaneously
has a normal skin colour and is alert and waking for feeds
has not lost more than 10% weight
Your baby's nappies: At least 5-6 heavy, wet nappies in 24 hours*
At least 2 dirty nappies in 24 hours, at least £2 coin size, yellow and runny and usually more*
Your breasts: Breasts and nipples are comfortable
Nipples are the same shape at the end of the feed as the start
Understands how using a dummy/nipple shields/infant formula can impact on breastfeeding

Midwife: if any responses not ticked: watch a full breastfeed, develop a care plan including revisiting positioning and attachment and/or refer for additional support. Consider specialist support if needed.
Feeding plan commenced: Yes/No: Plan to be documented in main notes if required

data.text: *This assessment tool was developed for use on or around day 5. If used at other times:

table_items.text: Sucking pattern: Swallows may be less audible until milk comes in day 3-4

Feed frequency: Day 1 at least 3-4 feeds After day 1 young babies will feed often and the pattern and number of feeds will vary from day to day. Being responsive to your baby's need to breastfeed for food, drink, comfort and security will ensure you have a good milk supply and a secure happy baby.

data.text: Adapted from © Unicef UK Baby Friendly Initiative Breastfeeding assessment tool.
Routine Postnatal Care Of Women And Their Babies/09127/4.0
Appendix D
Appendix E: Preliminary Equality Analysis
This assessment relates to: (please tick all that apply)

table_items.text: A change in a service to patients
A change to an existing policy
A change to the way staff work
What are you proposing to change?

11.4 When patients are discharged home from the consultant unit to community care, the discharge book on the postnatal ward or in the Co-Located Birthing Unit should be completed. Discharge documentation is sent electronically for all patients including patients outside of Chelmsford community providing the relevant information as documented in the discharge book. 11.5 In the event a patient and /or baby is transferred from the community or midwife led unit to the consultant unit, there should be a verbal handover between the referring professional and the receiving professional and the completion of the Ambulance transfer proforma (Refer to ‘Guideline for the transfer of mothers and their babies to different care settings'. Register number 06029) 13.3 If the temperature remains above 38C on one occasion or 37.5 on two occasions 2 hours apart or there are observable signs and symptoms, further assessment of the patient's condition should be made and midwifery and medical assistance sought. Blood cultures should be obtained with prior consent by the obstetric senior house officer for analysis. 16.3 For patients discharged from the consultant-led unit; the community midwifery team should be advised of all discharges from the Postnatal Ward by the ward clerk, or in her absence, the shift coordinator of the Postnatal Ward. An electronic copy of discharge is sent to relevant area.
Why are you making this change? (What will the change achieve?)
Who benefits from this change and how?
Is anyone likely to suffer any negative impact as a result of this change? If no, please record reasons here and sign and date this assessment. If yes, please complete a full EIA.
No as this falls within MEHT current guidelines.
a) Will you be undertaking any consultation as part of this change? b) If so, with whom?
Sarah Moon, Policies & Document Management Officer who will circulate to Midwifery/ obstetric team for clinical comment.
